justification: Across Studies 1a–1g, “participants indicated how much they were willing to pay … using a $0 to $3.00 slider to increase their winning chances,” making the slider-based WTP response the operational measure of how highly they valued an improvement.

Study 1g “measured valuations of improvements” by asking participants “how many captchas they were willing to solve” for a 10-percentage-point increase, so number of CAPTCHAs served as the behavioral gauge of valuation.

In Study 2b, after stating their WTP, “participants also completed a series of exploratory measures which asked how much regret they would anticipate experiencing,” indicating that self-report items quantified the construct of anticipated regret.
